monogr.title: A pronostication [sic] for the yere of our Lord God M.CCCCC.xliiii practysed by the right expert doctour in astronomy and phisycke Maister Cornelys Scute
monogr.author: Scute, Cornelys

div.head: ¶ To the Reder.
div.p:
BEfore I begin to come to my principall Pronosticatiō of this yere I haue taken in hand fyrst to rebuke the proheme of a certayne Pronosticatiō in the yere of our lorde a thousand fyue hundreth xliii. last past / made by one maister Henry swart / of Asperne: which dyd his vttermost to make the people beleue that the scyence of Astronomye is nothynge worth / but euyll: and the same is also a gret hyndraunce to the helth of mans body / and that some Phisytions do ascribe the cause of sycnesses (agaynst all reason) to come by the heauens / Starres / Planetes / Eclipses and Comettes. & cet. Sayeng / that if so be that this deuelisshe cōnyng had not ben taken
vp / many one shuld yet haue lyued longer. Cōmaundyng by his Pronostication to all Phisitions / that they shuld leue this connyng of Astronomye / alonely to practyse the right bokes of surgery. And also more iniury hath he done agaynst this excellent cōnyng / which were to longe here to expresse. Now to come to euery poynt afore wrytten only to testifye / that the same connyng of Astronomy is nedefall / & principally for Phisytions to mynister by to them that haue nede of it / for to helpe and cure the body of man. So it is of a truth / that Hipocrates / whose auctorotye and excellency in surgery he can not deny by reason / all this sayenge in the Greke tonge / now tourned in to Englysshe: who that shall gyue himself
•… ing of the sicknes shalbe of vomytynge coller or wamblynge of the mawe. All such lyke sycknes shall be apte to take all colde congealed maters: for as moche as the mone is not shadoed wt any other good Planetes / the man shall dye in the first quadrāt / that is to wyt / whan the mone shall come the thyrd syne folowyng: But if the mone be shadoed with any good planets / than shall the man ouer comme it in the first quadrant: that is to wyt / with in. vii. or. viii. days after. Also Gallene sayth in the ende of the same boke ī this maner: that a good Phisytion oughte to haue euer in his remembraunce the scyence of Astronomy / and that with all his endeuer ought to enquyre the day and tyme whan the sycknes began
or what tyme the hurte or fall / or other such lyke chaunsed / and must loke than after what sorte the heuens & starres stode at that tyme / consydring that here in this world chaunseth nothing / but by the procurement of the heuen aboue.

Also the gret lerned man Hermes Termegiscus / speketh after this maner: A good Phisytion whiche shall helpe a man by cōnyng / must beholde the constitution or inclination of heuē / with the starres / how they agre togither. Also Aristotle sayth / in the fyrst boke and second chapiter. Also Auicen Doctrina. i • . cap, vii, Secundum res celestes & res terrestres eueniūt, ille uero que res secuntur celestes, sunt sicut ea que stella • ū causa accidunt, est enim cūmulte ex stellis in uno coniungitur
loco et coniungitur soli, et prouenit ex hoc califactio multa. Item Abhomeron / Abinzoer / an excellent Phisytion sayth. libro primo cap. vii. in epilepsia paroxismi: Fieri cōsueuerunt ex operatione super celestium corporum que a deo uiuo & uero parfectionem & influentiam habere & resipere sciuntur. To this he putteth to thuetoritie of Arnoldus de uilla noua and Rasys and other lerned Phisytions / whose wordes here to declare wolde be to longe / remembryng also that here is wytnessed ynough agaynst the contrary sayeng of the aforesayd maister Henry: that the Scyence of Astronomy is a godly connynge & nedefull for Phisitions to know.

Item where as the aforesayd M. Henry sayth / that the Pronostications
saye not euer trew / is made answere ynough by Ptolome quin to ecētenis enuntiato. And also by Iohan Pontanium in the coment there vpon made / And also in prohemio libri su • . ii. de rebus celestib{us}. it wold be to longe to reherse word for word in this lytell boke. Item this M. Henry sayth in the same Prouosticatiō (without discretiō) of a chylde of. xii. yeres. slepyng naturally / goyng and standyng / that within two yeres had neither eten nor drōken / sayeng that euery one learned in that naturall connynge ought to applye them selues to make a naturall answer or reasō there vnto / the whiche he hoped to do afore her face: whiche is a straunge vnderstandyng to gyue there vnto a naturall reason / which is befall
contrary agaynst all nature / folowynge the sentence of Hipocrates in Aphoris. 14. where he sayth that it is agaynst goddes commaundement to gyue confydence to the pronostication: so say I that it is true that we shall not beleue it so faythfully as the word of god in the gospell or by the prophetes which can not lye in no wyse / but must be euē as they be spoken iuxta illud, Mat. xxiiii. but it may be lauful to gyue such credence there vnto as we gyue to phisycke & other. We none otherwyse doo dispose than the naturall sygnes do declare / beholdīg that the workes be wonderous exceding all iudgementes of nature. And ye shall vnderstand that I haue not sayd this before mencyoned not in derisyon or to shame the aforesayd
maister Henry / but alonly for his vnlauful opinion that he had to argue vpon agaynst thexellent connyng of Astronomy.
